key_work.brief_description: During the 17th and 18th centuries, artists responded to the flourishing of science and philosophy. In the late 18th and into the 19th century, artists challenged these values, instead emphasising the role of emotions in understanding the world.

end.title: Jason and the Argonauts [DVD]
end.creator_credit: Don Chaffey, Charles H. Schneer and Columbia Pictures
end.brief_description: Stemming from Greek mythology, this is the tale of the voyages of the intrepid Jason and his Argonauts on a quest to find the legendary Golden Fleece. He and his crew must brave all manner of dangers and face a host of terrifying foes, including the seven-headed Hydra, fighting skeletons, bloodthirsty Harpies and the invincible colossus Talos. It is also a tale of love, as the beautiful Medea risks everything for Jason and his quest. For its time, the special effects of Ray Harryhausen were given accolades by the critics. Stars Todd Armstrong as Jason and Nancy Kovack as Medea.

start.title: Mighty Joe Young
start.creator_credit: Ernest B Schoedsack, John Ford, Merian C. Cooper, Argosy Pictures, Arko Productions and RKO Radio Pictures
start.brief_description: Following in the footsteps of King Kong, this is a fantasy story about another giant ape by the name of Joe Young, his devoted owner Jill Young (Terry Moore) and the exploitation Joe Young suffers when he is taken from his native country of Africa back to America and the bright lights of Hollywood. Cast also includes Ben Johnson and Robert Armstrong.

end.creator_credit: Sam Raimi, Ida Gearon, Bruce Campbell, Robert Tapert, Introvision International, Renaissance Pictures, The De Laurentiis Company, Anthony Tremblay and Ivan Raimi
end.brief_description: Ash is transported back to medieval days, where he is captured by the dreaded Lord Arthur. Aided by the deadly chainsaw that has become his only friend, Ash is sent on a perilous mission to recover the Book of the Dead, a powerful tome that gives its owner the power to summon an army of ghouls.

links.description: The most iconic scene in Jason and the Argonauts features stop-motion skeleton warriors. It took Harryhausen four months to make the three-minute scene. It was recreated as an homage in Sam Raimi’s Army of Darkness, using the Introvision process instead of the traditional rear projection.

start.title: The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the ring
start.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, Fran Walsh, Tim Sanders, New Line Cinema and Wingnut Films
start.brief_description: Iconic adaptation of J R R Tolkien’s fantasy epic, “The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the rings” is the first instalment of the “Rings” trilogy. Director Peter Jackson (Heavenly creatures, The Frighteners, Meet the Feebles) went to incredible lengths to re-create Tolkien’s fantastical vision to the screen, by building extensive realistic sets in his native New Zealand, and by employing a slew of gifted special effects artists. In short, Frodo Baggins, a kind-hearted and earnest hobbit, is entrusted with the gallant mission to return a powerful ring from whence it came - Mount Doom, the only place where it can be destroyed. Failure to do so will result in the destruction of the earth, as the powerful ring is capable of unleashing inestimable evil. Guided by Gandalf, a powerful wizard, Frodo is accompanied on his treacherous journey by three hobbit friends, a dwarf, an elf and several humans. This heroic quest invokes all the necessary thrills of an adventure picture, whilst satiating the exacting standards of an audience inured to CGI wizardry, and gratifying legions of zealous Tolkien fans. With ambitious battle scenes and stupendous set pieces, this grand and masterful cinematic spectacle kept most viewers utterly enthralled, whilst earning Jackson almost universal praise for capturing Tolkien’s mythopoeic narrative and elegiac tone.

links.description: Peter Jackson created a remake of King Kong in 2005. Unlike the first King Kong film in 1933, Jackson brought the mighty primate to life through an actor wearing motion capture rather than practical effects – something he’d perfected with Golem in Lord of the Rings.

end.title: 2001: A Space Odyssey
end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 1968
end.brief_description: Humanity finds a mysterious object buried beneath the lunar surface and sets off to find its origins with the help of HAL 9000, the world’s most advanced super computer, in Stanley Kubrick’s masterpiece, which pushed cinematic narratives and special effects.

constellations_other.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_other.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

constellations_other.name: Sounds unreal
constellations_other.description: A history of syncing sound effects, a craft known as Foley in the USA and bootstepping in the UK.

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_other.name: Kaleidoscopic colour: Chromotrope
constellations_other.description: A focus on distinctive and innovative examples of pattern, colour and movement.

constellations_other.name: The Kubrick connection
constellations_other.description: The visual effects for Blade Runner drew on a number of techniques from other iconic films, including two of Stanley Kubrick's masterpieces.

constellations_other.description: In No Code’s sci-fi thriller players take command of a multi-national space station’s artificial intelligence system to help the sole survivor solve the mystery of a missing crew and why the station is wildly off course.
